title: When do you use short form verbs in Japanese? - Quora

response.answer_text: You just have to learn from experience. It’s always safer to use ます and です at first. Sometimes, the other person will imply that you’re too formal. For example: You: 食べません Him: 食べない？ Generally, I’d just get a feel for the conversation. If you’re in Kansai, it’s much easier to just start using plain form. Personally, I usually err on the side of politeness. You can usually use the short form and maintain appropriate politeness by adding です. For example: 決めなかったです。 決めたんです。 いいじゃないですか？ などなど。 Often, in casual but polite speech, you’ll hear something like this: いいじゃないですか -> いいじゃないっすか？ It’s still polite, but it feels less stilted. If this doesn’t feel natural, I wouldn’t do it.
